In flashback sequences we see Jenny (Diane Keaton) and Charlie (Eugene Levy) fawning over their young Blue Tang with short term remembery (sic) loss.

With coaxing from the still young Nemo, Dory decides to cross the ocean in search for her parents.  But she needs help due to her memory deficiency.  Reluctantly, Marlin agrees to help.  What could he say, Dory was influential in rescuing his son.  The trio is headed for the aquarium at Morrow Bay, California.  They have the expected resolvable difficulties along the way and eventually make it, although Dory is separated from Marlin and Nemo.  But not to worry, she finds unexpected help from a grouchy, but inventive octopus named Hank (Ed ONeill), a farsighted whale shark (Katlin Olson) and a beluga whale (Ty Burrell) who has lost his sonar abilities.

The Disney/Pixar folks are on the top of their game as usual with their beautiful animation.  Even their often dark shots of various underwater pipes come across clear and distinct.  In darken oceans we can still see detail of sunken boats, tires and other various junk, dumped by man. As it is, this is a wonderful film, with a proper dose of charm and morality and with some engaging action sequences.  It just doesnt hold up to the studios best efforts.  Still recommended.

Finding Dory
 Pixar, the wonderful animated film company invented by Apple founder Steve Jobs, introduced us in "Finding Nemo" to a big eyed blue fish named Dory.  Dory suffers from a brain disorder that prevents her recall of events in her short term memory.  Now she has her own movie, "Finding Dory".  Only the wonderful Pixar company (now part of Disney) could make such a colorful, fun, funny and delightful film about a brain impaired fish.  Wow.
 In the full Pixar tradition, the movie has many moments where side characters to provide humor while advancing the story.  Dory herself, Nemo and Nemo's dad provide the core characters but lots of others come in and out.  A  fast acting octopus helps Dory out, often against his better judgement.  A couple of sea lions with a London East End accent guard their sun spot rock from a goofy interloper while helping Dory along her way.  Some surf guy sea turtles carry Nemo and his dad all the way across the Pacific ocean.  Each of these characters, even ones we see only briefly, have full personalities that we can enjoy.
 Besides the inspiring story and the Pixar perfect animation we also have a collection of well known actors to voice the characters.  Ellen DeGeneres again voices Dory, the game but often thwarted fish.  Albert Brooks, Ed O'Neil (Modern Family) and Ty Burrell (also on American Family) all pitch in.  Up and coming young actress  Kaitlin Olson plays the voice of a dim eyed whale shark.  Diane Keaton, Eugene Levy, Idris Elba, Dominic West (also playing the the current "Warcraft") and Bill Harder  all help.  Finally, Sigourney Weaver plays the voice of herself as the announcer voice at a sea life center.  Whew.
 Director Andrew Stanton won Oscars for two other Pixar films, "Wall-E" and "Finding Nemo".  He also wrote the story and the screenplay.  Angus MacLane helped write the screen play and also had a hand in other very successful Pixar projects.
 On a $200 million budget the family safe PG film took in a stellar $187 world wide over the three day week end and early Thursday night showings.  The domestic box office had a pre-weekend estimate of $100 million but smashed that by taking in $136 million to add to $51 in overseas earnings.  This four and a half saw blade movie will be enjoyed by the whole family.

The Good:
From the very beginning, the film does an excellent job in catching us up from the previous Finding Nemo film. (Which was 13 years ago!) It was nice to get see so many familiar faces from the past film and to be introduced to new characters in this sequel.
Something you may notice that's a little different from the previous film is that it's a bit more emotionally rich. Naturally, you'll have some funny and entertaining moments, but this time around there are a few more sentimental moments. I don't think it's anything comparable to "Bambi's mom dying" level of emotional. Although, there are some moments that may cause a tiny little lump in your throat to climb up.
Ellen DeGeneres is absolutely perfect for the character of Dory. It would be simply impossible trying to imagine anyone else being Dory. Her running jokes are funny throughout the entire film. Ellen, and the writers of the movie, bring forth a lot more depth in Dory's character. She's not simply the silly side-kick character for comedic relief. They showed through her (including all of the other supporting characters) just what makes Dory such a special character.

Moreover, it was especially refreshing to see yet another female lead character, but this time around it's a disabled female lead character. If you were like me, Dory's short-term memory used to be only perceived as comedic relief. In this sequel, while there are still funny moments, there are also moments that force you to look at disabilities (of other characters as well) in a different way.
The Bad:
Even though the movie isn't long (only 97 mins), there still seemed to be a few slow moving scenes. Now to be fair, those scenes just set up another good or emotional moment. However, with children in mind, those slow moments may lose younger children's attention.
As mentioned above, this movie is a little more emotionally heavy than Finding Nemo. There are some sad moments that may just require an additional conversation from parents with their children. It's nothing over the top, but just something to keep in mind for audiences under the age of six years old perhaps.
Look, maybe this is nitpicking, (and I know that this is a kiddie cartoon) but the ending did get a little too far fetched. In comparison to Finding Nemo, even though they all go on crazy adventures, it got a little over the top even for this cartoon.

Beyond that, I'd probably say feel free on skipping on the 3D for this film as well. There just didn't seem to be any memorable special effects that would warrant spending the extra money for that 3D ticket. Maybe it was just me, but the 3D glasses also seemed to make the movie a tad bit darker, and not as vibrantly colorful as the previous film.

The Reason:
In my opinion, I think that Finding Nemo was a better movie for younger children, because it was so much more light-hearted, colorful, and energetic. I do believe that Finding Dory is a great film for kids maybe between the ages of 6-12 years. (Adults will enjoy this as well) I think that Finding Dory is a great platform to spark meaningful conversations within families about differently-abled individuals in society. This is what make movies so special. They tap into our everyday lives, and find a way to have us relate to other people in ways didn't originally imagine.
So by all means, feel free to watch Finding Dory. It's obviously a perfect family movie, and don't be surprised if you find yourself having some meaningful conversations afterwards. Oh and speaking of afterwards, watch the movie all the way past the credits for a bonus scene.
